description: From Spanish embargar (“to arrest”), from Latin in- + Vulgar Latin *barra. More at embarrass.

entries.meaning: An order by the government prohibiting ships from leaving port.
A ban on trade with another country.
examples: Instead he [Jefferson] proposed an embargo, an end to all trade between America and England.

entries.meaning: A temporary ban on making certain information public.
examples: This copy of the federal budget is under embargo until 2 p.m.

entries.meaning: A heavy burden or severe constraint on action or expenditure.

verbs.description: embargo (third-person singular simple present embargoes, present participle embargoing, simple past and past participle embargoed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impose an embargo on trading certain goods with another country.
(transitive) To impose an embargo on a document.
